title: Sunsama vs Todoist for Minimalists
meta_description: Sunsama vs Todoist for minimalists who want a clean daily task list without guided planning rituals or structured daily review sessions.
constraint_lens: You want to list and check off tasks without guided rituals, planning sessions, or layered workflows.

verdict.summary: Todoist wins for minimalists who just want a clean daily task list. You can add tasks instantly and view them in a simple Today list without going through a planning routine. Sunsama is built around a structured daily planning flow that encourages reviewing and scheduling tasks each day. If daily planning sessions become mandatory, Sunsama fails first.
verdict.decision_rule: If daily planning sessions become mandatory, Sunsama fails first.

sections.heading: Why this matters for Minimalists
sections.content: You said you want to list tasks without structured daily rituals. As a minimalist, extra steps like guided planning screens or daily shutdown prompts feel unnecessary when your goal is simply to see and complete tasks. A straightforward list view fits you better.

bullets.point: Daily planning screen that asks you to select and schedule tasks for the day
bullets.why_it_matters: It helps you focus intentionally, but it introduces a required review step before starting work.

bullets.point: Calendar based task scheduling with drag and drop time blocks
bullets.why_it_matters: You can assign specific time slots to tasks, yet this adds structure beyond a simple checklist.

bullets.point: End of day review and carryover flow
bullets.why_it_matters: It encourages reflection and rollover, but it creates a ritual that may feel heavy if you just want to check items off.

bullets.point: Quick add task field available from any view
bullets.why_it_matters: You can type a task and press enter without entering a planning mode.

bullets.point: Simple Today and Upcoming list views
bullets.why_it_matters: Your daily tasks appear in a clean list without requiring scheduling into time blocks.

bullets.point: Optional features like labels and filters can be ignored
bullets.why_it_matters: You can keep everything as a basic list and avoid deeper structuring if you prefer.

sections.heading: Where each tool can break down

items.fails_when: You feel required to go through a daily planning session before seeing or completing tasks.
items.what_to_do_instead: Use Todoist if you want immediate access to a simple task list.

items.fails_when: You need enforced daily reviews and time blocking to stay focused.
items.what_to_do_instead: Use Sunsama if structured daily planning helps you stay accountable.

sections.heading: When this verdict might flip
sections.content: If you start struggling with distraction and need a guided daily planning ritual to decide what to work on, Sunsama may feel more supportive despite the added structure.

sections.heading: Quick decision rules
rules: If you want a clean task list with no ritual, choose Todoist.
If daily planning sessions feel like extra work, avoid Sunsama.
If structured daily reviews help you focus, Sunsama may fit better.

faqs.q: Is Sunsama only for people who like structure?
faqs.a: It is designed around daily planning and scheduling, which suits people who want a guided routine.

faqs.q: Can I keep Todoist very simple?
faqs.a: Yes, you can use it as a basic checklist without labels, filters, or complex project structures.
It strongly encourages scheduling tasks into calendar slots as part of its daily workflow.

faqs.q: Which tool feels lighter day to day?
faqs.a: Todoist generally feels lighter because you can open it and immediately see your task list.
